units.title: Neural induction with dual‑SMAD inhibitors
units.text: Thus, we use the dual‑SMAD inhibitors dorsomorphin (4 μM) and SB‑431542 (10 μM) in neurobasal media with the vitamin A‑containing B27 supplement for neural induction (Figs. 1 and 2a–c).
units.rationale: Specifies the chemicals and concentrations required to induce neural fate.

units.title: NR formation and amplification medium exchange
units.text: The successfully induced cultures are replated using Dispase, which allows the detachment of neuroectodermal cell clusters. The clusters of neuroectodermal cells give rise to NRs. Upon replating, we switch to the amplification medium with EGF (10 ng/mL) and FGF2 (10 ng/mL). Half the medium is exchanged every other day with fresh medium containing 2× EGF (20 ng/mL) and 2× FGF2 (20 ng/mL) to maintain the final concentration at 10 ng/mL.
units.rationale: Describes how to generate neural rosettes and maintain growth factor levels.

units.title: Isolation of single neural rosettes (SNRs)
units.text: Identify large SNRs (>200 μm in diameter) with a clearly visible single lumen for isolation under a stereoscope (Fig. 2e,f). Carefully separate SNRs from the adjacent tissue using the glass hook and gently detach each one from the bottom of the dish (Fig. 2f and Supplementary Video 2). Transfer isolated SNRs to 96‑well plate (one SNR per well) using a P200 filtered pipette and return the plate to the incubator.
units.rationale: Provides the manual steps to obtain individual rosettes for organoid generation.

units.title: SNR‑derived organoid propagation in suspension
units.text: Change the medium every other day for 2 weeks by removing 50 % of the old medium (150 μL) and adding 150 μL fresh amplification medium with 2× concentrations of FGF2 and EGF to achieve final FGF2 and EGF concentrations of 10 ng/mL. Take images of SNR‑derived organoids at 1, 7 and 14 d post‑isolation to document organoid development (Figs. 3 and 4).
units.rationale: Ensures consistent growth and monitoring of organoids during early culture.

units.title: Matrigel (MG) embedding of organoids
units.text: Place a box of P200 pipette tips in a −20 °C freezer for at least 15 min to cool them before use for embedding. Thaw MG aliquot(s) on ice 1–2 h before embedding; 30 μL of MG will be needed for embedding each organoid. Cut an ~40 mm square of Parafilm and disinfect it by spraying with 70 % ethanol. Fill the lid with MG droplets containing organoids, incubate at 37 °C for 30 min to gelate, then transfer the droplets into a 10 cm Petri dish with organoid propagation medium and place on an orbital shaker for long‑term culture.
units.rationale: Details the preparation and execution of MG embedding to support organoid expansion.

units.title: Preparation of amplification medium
units.text: Amplification medium (for use in Steps 26–45): for a working aliquot, combine N2 and B27 media in a 1:1 mix, warm it, and add EGF (10 ng/mL) and FGF2 (10 ng/mL) immediately before use. Use freshly prepared. Do not store.
units.rationale: Gives the exact composition of the medium that sustains SNR growth.

units.title: Dissociation of 1‑month‑old organoids for scRNA‑seq (Option A)
units.text: Transfer 1‑month‑old organoids (before MG embedding) to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube using a P200 pipette tip cut to avoid damaging the organoids. Let organoids settle to the bottom, aspirate the medium and rinse once with sterile PBS. Discard the papain solution, add 500 μL of trypsin inhibitor, and incubate for 10 min at 37 °C. Dissociate organoids into single cells by repeated pipetting with a P1000 pipette.
units.rationale: Provides a concise protocol for obtaining single‑cell suspensions for sequencing.

units.title: Immunohistochemistry of organoid sections (Option C)
units.text: Fixation: transfer organoids to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube using a P200 pipette tip cut to avoid damaging the organoids. Let organoids settle to the bottom, aspirate the medium and rinse once with sterile PBS. Discard the supernatant, add 250 μL of 4 % PFA and incubate overnight at 4 °C. Dilute primary antibodies in 3 % BSA with 0.3 % Triton‑X 100 in PBS. Cover the sections and incubate overnight at 4 °C in a humidifying chamber.
units.rationale: Outlines the key steps for staining organoid sections to visualize cell types.

units.title: Slice patch‑clamp electrophysiology (Option D)
units.text: Organoid preparation and mounting: transfer a 5‑month‑old organoid to a 6 cm dish with ice‑cold, oxygenated cutting ACSF using a P1000 pipette tip cut to avoid damaging the organoid. Slicing: cut 350‑µm‑thick slices using the vibratome set to 100 Hz frequency, 1.2 mm amplitude and a slow (3–6 mm/min) forward movement velocity. Patch‑clamp experiment: transfer a slice into the recording chamber using a wide Pasteur pipette. Place a harp slice grid over the slice to hold it in place during the experiment and start perfusion with oxygenated ACSF at a flow rate of ~3 mL/min.
units.rationale: Summarizes the preparation and recording steps for functional electrophysiology.

units.title: Thawing and plating of PS cells (Stage 1)
units.text: Warm a 6‑well plate with MG‑coated wells by placing it in a 37 °C, 5 % CO₂ incubator for ~30 min or keeping it at room temperature for 1 h in a biosafety cabinet. Take a frozen aliquot of cells from liquid nitrogen and thaw the aliquot by dipping it in a 37 °C water bath while monitoring the process every few seconds. Spin cells down at 1,000 rpm (300 g) for 4 min at room temperature. Add 3 mL of stem cell medium with Y‑27632 and gently resuspend the pellet using the 5 mL serological pipet.
units.rationale: Covers the initial cell recovery steps required before any differentiation.
